newsitem.title: JAPAN: CWB says Japan grain shipments soon back to normal.
newsitem.headline: CWB says Japan grain shipments soon back to normal.

text.p: Canadian Wheat Board (CWB) chief commissioner Lorne Hehn said on Thursday that grain shipments to Japan will be back to normal by early April, after transportation problems in Canada caused a severe backlog of vessels at West Coast ports.
"I believe that grain shipments to Japan will be back to normal by early April. We met the (Japanese) Food Agency officials here and talked about it," Hehn told Reuters.
Heavy snow, extreme cold and equipment failure led to delays in rail shipments to Pacific ports from grain-growing regions in Canada since early January.
The Canadian Wheat Board faces more than C$15 million in demurrage charges and has acknowledged deferring sales.
But Hehn also said that despite the delays, Canada will not lose its market share in Japan to other countries such as the United States and Australia.
"One of the reasons we have good market share in this country is good quality. We have taken a number of steps in Canada to ensure this kind of disruption is minimised in the future," he said.
Hehn was accompanying Canadian Agriculture Minister Ralph Goodale on a trade mission to Japan.
Some Food Agency officials have said they are increasingly doubtful about the credibility of the CWB as a stable supplier because of the shipment delays.
